originalTitle: South Sudan army threat to 'spare no-one' condemned
title: Helpers Want Peace for Everyone in South Sudan!
content:
Hello, my wonderful friends! I'm your special news reporter, and I'm here to share some important news from our amazing continent, Africa. Today, we're going to talk about a beautiful country called South Sudan and why grown-ups around the world want everyone there to be safe and happy.

Meet South Sudan!

South Sudan is a country in eastern Africa. It's quite a new country, full of wonderful people, big rivers, and exciting animals like elephants and giraffes! Imagine wide-open spaces and lots of sunshine. People in South Sudan love to laugh, play, and work together, just like you and your family. Did you know? South Sudan became its own country on July 9, 2011! That makes it one of the world's newest countries. How cool is that?

A Bit About Grown-Up Talk

Sometimes, grown-ups have important jobs. In every country, there's usually an army. The army's job is to keep everyone safe and protect the country. They are like very brave guardians. But sometimes, things can get a little tricky, and people might say things that are not very helpful or kind. Recently, some people who are part of the army in South Sudan said some very strong words. These words sounded like they might want to hurt regular people. And when we say 'regular people,' we mean everyone who is not a soldier – like moms, dads, grandmas, grandpas, and especially kids like you!

Why Are Words So Important?

Words are super powerful, my friends! They can make us feel happy, or sad, or even scared. Think about when your friend says, "Let's play together!" – that makes you happy, right? But what if someone says, "I don't want to play with you!" – that can make you sad. When grown-ups say angry words that sound like they want to hurt people, it can make everyone feel very worried and scared. These kinds of words can make people want to fight instead of play. Everyone wants to feel safe in their homes and when they go to school or play outside. Did you know? Using kind words can make new friends, help solve problems, and make the world a happier place! It’s like magic!

Who Are the Helpers? Meet the UN!

Luckily, there are big helpers in the world! They are called the United Nations, or the UN for short. The UN is like a super big team of grown-ups from almost every country in the world. Their main job is to help countries work together, stay peaceful, and make sure everyone is safe and has what they need. The UN has a special team in South Sudan. They are called the UN Mission, and their job is to help keep the peace and look out for everyone. When they heard those strong, angry words from the army people, they became very, very worried. They were 'gravely concerned,' which means they were super, super worried! They told everyone that it's not okay to say words that might make people want to hurt each other. The UN wants everyone, especially the regular people and kids, to be safe. They want words to be used for helping and bringing people together, not for scaring or fighting. Did you know? The UN does many amazing things around the world! They help get food to people who are hungry, they help kids go to school, and they help doctors take care of sick people. They are true superheroes!

Why Peace is the Best!

Imagine your classroom, or your home, or your playground. You want it to be a place where everyone feels safe, right? Where you can play, learn, and laugh without feeling scared. That's what peace feels like! When there is peace, kids can go to school every day and learn new things. They can play outside with their friends. Families can work and grow food, and everyone can sleep soundly at night. Peace means happy faces and bright futures for everyone. When there are angry words and fighting, it's very hard for people to live normal lives. Kids might not be able to go to school, and it can be scary for families. That's why the UN and many other good grown-ups are working so hard to make sure there is peace in South Sudan. Did you know? Many schools around the world teach kids about peace. It’s a very important lesson for everyone, big and small!

What Can We All Do?

Even though you are kids, you can help make the world a more peaceful place! How? By being kind to your friends and family. By using kind words. By sharing your toys. By listening to your teachers and parents who teach you how to be good and thoughtful. We can all wish for peace for the people in South Sudan. We can hope that all the grown-ups there will choose kind words and work together to keep everyone safe and happy. Because everyone, everywhere, deserves to live in peace and safety! Let's all think about peace today and spread kindness wherever we go! That's all for now from your friendly African news reporter!
summary: Helpers called the United Nations are very worried about strong, angry words spoken in South Sudan that sounded like they might hurt regular people, and they want everyone to be safe and live in peace.
whyMatters: It matters because everyone, especially kids, deserves to feel safe and happy without worrying about angry words or fighting. We want peace so kids can go to school, play, and live good lives.

originalTitle: Uganda's military chief denies army assaulted Bobi Wine's wife
title: Uganda's military chief denies army assaulted Bobi Wine's wife
content: Barbara Kyagulanyi, married to the opposition leader, says she refused to reveal her husband's whereabouts.

content: The worst flooding in a generation hits Mozambique with teams from Brazil, South Africa and the UK helping with the rescue.

title: Biscuit factory explosion in Greece kills at least four
content: An overnight explosion at a biscuit factory in Trikala, Greece, has killed at least four workers.

title: Winter storm causes deaths, power outages and flight cancellations in US
content: At least 819,000 homes and businesses are without power, and travel is disrupted nationwide.

title: Israel says it has retrieved remains of final Gaza hostage

title: 'This is horrifying' - Minneapolis residents reel from second deadly shooting
content: Two people have been shot dead by federal agents in the city in recent weeks, leaving many angry and frustrated.

title: France debates under-15s social media ban endorsed by Macron
content: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu has said he will use a fast-track procedure to get the legislation on the books by September.

content: BBC Sport looks at some of the players that have been linked with moves before the Premier League transfer deadline on 2 February at 19:00 GMT.

originalTitle: Besiktas pay £11m for Abraham - to sell him to Villa
title: Besiktas pay £11m for Abraham - to sell him to Villa
content: Besiktas pay £11.2m to Roma for Tammy Abraham - as the Turkish club prepare to sell him to Aston Villa.

originalTitle: 'Heading football likely to have contributed to McQueen's brain disease'
title: 'Heading football likely to have contributed to McQueen's brain disease'
content: An inquest concludes that "it is likely that repetitive head impacts, sustained by heading the ball while playing football, contributed to the CTE" which was a factor in the former Scotland footballer's death.
